author: IVEngineering

description.text:
This is a desktop-size, open-source milling machine in kitform, built from lasercut parts.
We know several people have tried to put a Dremel inside a Makerbot, but we don't think this makes much sense. You'll have a high center of gravity and a light frame. We love our Makerbots, but we think if we put a Dremel toolhead in them, they'll just vibrate apart :) We designed something from the ground up to be stable, rugged and still light-weight enough to be carried around. (actually, the one I'm showing in Paris this weekend now features a suitcase handle on the steel frame) The machine has an open floor, allowing it to do a milling operation on a large object. The machine was specifically developed to have a low center of gravity and be a portable, yet stable platform. The machine uses a microATX 12V power supply and Makerbot electronics The current version has a 175x175 mm cutting area. The machine can easily be enlarged along the X-axis, as the machine is built from a number of modular parts. There's a short video of the working machine on http://www.repairablemachines.com/updates.html
You'll also find some stuff we made with it there. The plans are uploaded here and on www.repairablemachines.com.
We also make kits for this machine, we can provide you with all the parts you need to assemble this into a fully working milling machine UPDATE SEPTEMBER 2011: we published version 1.08 of this machine
It now has:
-improved accuracy, better than 0.2mm
-version numbering engraved on all parts
-a more rigid Z-axis

Assembly instructions and full documentation can be found at:
http://www.repairablemachines.com A parts list is published on:
http://www.repairablemachines.com/partlist_miniCNC_v108.htm

description.text: Castle front of a thing I made in blender. LOL hope u like download, and check my stuff out.
Smartphone bike holder for Sony Xperia Sola.

1) Print either "part 1" or "part 1 splitted 1 & 2". If you chose the second option, glue the two parts together. The "hole" part can help to align the parts while gluing. Don't forget to put M4 nuts in the hole before gluing.

2) For better fixation of your phone, bend the clip a little bit inward using hot air.

3) Print "part 2".

4) Put the screws in "part 2" and mount the holder on the stem at your bike.

Additional materials needed:
2x M4 18mm Cylindrical head hexagon socket screw
2x M4 nut

description.text: A mod to increase the power / range of the gun.

Print part
Remove barrel extension
Remove bolt
Remove all external screws on the main gun (not the stock)
Unscrew the two screws holding the spring holder (right hand end of the spring)
Use printed part inside the spring holder
(Optionally - drill out air restrictor / valve from the right hand end)
Reassemble
Fire further A photo of the internals is an easy find on the internet:
http://modworks.blogspot.com/2010/01/nerf-longstrike-internals-guide.html

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jn5SnI3Ssph

A printable flexible coaster.   
I've really admired Zomboe's chainmail, and printed quite a bit of it. However, I noticed that if a link twisted out of place, then the chainmail would "buckle" and it would be very difficult to fix.  
I thought about it, and tried printing two layers of chainmail, one on top of the other. This would make the links completely closed loops, and prevent them from rotating. This worked great, except that the horizontal bridges for the two layers would stick together, so I hacked the code to add an offset to the bottom layer. Current versions should now print with no rework or wiggling necessary - the chainmail should be flexible.  
An unexpected outcome was that the double layer chainmail displays some really interesting behavior. Try bending it up by holding opposite corners, and see what happens to the loose corners. Flip it and try it again.  
Extra bonus: there is a module in there called bitchain() that helps you set up multicolor chainmail prints.

Make sure to print it at 0.27mm layer height. The model is built in exact multiples of this amount.  
You can change this value in the OpenSCAD file if you want.  
You can also try printing at larger sizes. It works well and is fun to play with.

comments.text: I know this has been awhile, so you might not remember much about this piece or even be looking for questions. But I want to print this on my Up mini and it only let's me select layer heights to choose from a limited selection, .25 and .3 being the closest.   I did download OpenSCAD and edit the layer height value to .3, thinking this would be the better than .25.  OpenSCAD successfully rendered it and I exported the STL.  ( Thanks for making  something that pushed to learn how to do at least this,  Before this, I have only been editing in Tinkercad) .  But the UP hangs when it tries to slice my edited version.   So just to see what would happen, I printed your original .27 version using .25 layer height.     The result won't decouple, as expected, but it's close enough to make me want it even more.
comments.author: ebmcginnis

author: bensanders

description.text:
Trilobite from the collection of Museum Victoria
Species name: Metacanthina sp
Specimen registration number: P 149623
Found: near Alnif, Morocco
Geological time period: Devonian Main picture acknowledgement: Ben Healley, Museum Victoria More details about the specimen can be found on Museum Victoria Collections

This model is from a scan of a fossil from the collection of Museum Victoria. A small portion of the original matrix has been removed from the base of the model.   
The full model has been successfully printed in PLA on a Replicator 2 on the standard medium settings.   
We found that greater definiton in the print can be achieved with the trilobite in a vertical orientation. In the additional STL files (Cut 1 and Cut 2),  the model has been split to facilitate vertical printing.

  • renamed some varaibles to make more easy to use with "MakerBot's Thingiverse Customizer"
  • fixed some alignment issues with hexagons
  • fixed off by 1 error for rows and columns
  • fixed some manifoldness issues with cutouts
    0.3
  • fixed up some translates to properly account for the chosen wall thickness
  • added option to make hexagons...but it's not very pretty
    0.2
  • added union command so all the cells are joined as one solid piece
    0.1
  • First implementation

• Measure and count your bees
  • Open .scad file and change values in the *UserVariables Section for bee length, bee diameter, wall thickness, no. of rows, no. of columns, and decide whether you want Hexagonal or Cylindrical holes.
  • Render the file in OpenSCAD to check it looks ok
  • Export as .stl
  • Print
  • Hang
  • House some bees!

author: Whoops

description.text:
Dual #MakeItFloat and #CatchTheWind entry

This is the Livo 3, a trimaran (three-hulled sailboat).

Its two outer hulls swing into three different possible positions:

  • It can be locked into the fully extended configuration, which is the predicted main sailing configuration and should provide maximum speed and stability, especially in side-wind.
  • It can be configured into a middle position with the out hulls at an intermediate distance from the central hull, and swooping backward, for increased maneuverability in tight areas.
  • Finally, it can be 'closed, with the outer hull adjacent to the central one, as to occupy minimal space on a theoretical trailer, or when docked at port.

This is the third boat, in a series that I have made as summer vacation projects (hence the name and the three hulls), although the first two were not 3D printed, but carved in wood.

The files are still temporary, but when it is done the boat should be fully functional, and steer well, as well as go at a decent speed with some wind, based on results with previous tests.

Coins (in dedicated slots) will be used as moveable ballast on the leeward side to keep the boat level.

Any suggestions, (especially sailing/nautical ones) will be greatly appreciated.

Apologies if the terminology is not proper :).

Updates

v 1.1

  • The keel is now a removable "daggerboard" to more accurately represent modern trimarans.
  • the crossbar connecting the rudders has a more aerodynamic shape and a handle in the center

v 1.2

  • modified the rudder to 'flow' with the crossbar
  • added a cap for the boom and mast to hold the sail/rigging
  • strengthened the hinges pins
  • added hooks to secure hulls in the desired position with string or rubber bands for extra strength
  • made crossbar angled
  • added the 3 separate crossbars for each position

v 1.3

  • modified rudder hold in outriggers to make it simpler to print
  • re-sized rudder accordingly
  • added coin ballast holder (sized for dimes)
  • re-sized pins with better tolerance
  • added hookups for boom-line (in the back) and sail-line (in the front)

v 1.4

  • cleaned up model so it can slice and print
  • modified coin ballast holder with flat bottom for easier loading

v 1.5

  • uploaded individual STL files with some minor modification after we printed all the small parts
  • couldn't find the 5mm dowel for the mast so we decided to use kitchen skewers. the mast base and top were modified accordingly, and a connector was added to get enough length (files are called ****skwr)
  • the sail is made of a plastic file folder

  • we also designed a base holder, we'll put it up if there is time

  • our printer only does 10x10x10 cm, so the hulls, rudderbars and other large pieces don't fit. we will cut them and print them in smaller pieces, then glue them.
    for the side hull we incorporated slots and connector to make the assembly easier and sturdier.
  • added a 'collar' to the daggerboard holder, to keep the two pieces (rear and middle) tight after reglueing. it is not required if the print is in one piece (still looks good ;))
  • When you award us the new printer, we will be able to print them whole! :)

when the boat is assembled, we will finally be able to test how many coins can the outriggers carry !

since there are already a ton of files and pics, we will document the build in the connected "I MADE ONE" page

THE WATER TEST !

it floats!!! :) :)
the glue seals seem to be holding well.
the boat is relatively low on the water but it moves around happily.

COIN TEST
at the first try it only held 17 coins, dispersed on the outriggers, before starting to take in water. the water came in from the back, and a lot of the coins where on the stern side.

tried again but with more care of putting in the dimes more towards the bow.
the picture above is at 24 dimes (12 per side), another 4-12 or so can be added before causing the boat to sink. it needs to be done with caution and the placement is important.

if the coins were also put in the main hull, the number raised up to 52 before it sunk.
with careful placement i think that the $6 limit could be reached

separate STL files are now uploaded
we are still printing/testing, so there might be ulterior changes

current version is 1.5

printed parts:
central hull
righ hull
left hull
4x hinges
8x pins
2x rudder
2x ruddercap
daggerboad
daggerbard lock
boom pivot
boom cap
mast cap
mast connector (for skewer mast only)
6x coin ballast holders (hold 20 dimes each)

extra:
3mm dowel (boom)
5mm dowel (mast) we ended up using skewers, ~3mm diameter
plastic or fabric for the sail
glue
rubberbands
string /line

The hulls need to be printed upside down. everything else standing/
the daggerboard can be printed standing or flat.

depending on the printer resolution, you might have to adjust the relative size of the pins and possibly the arm hinges
To assemble the boat, put the extender pins into the arms, and apply a dab of superglue. Then, without getting the glue on the arms/hinges, put the pins into their designated spots on the hulls. Once dried, the arms should swing in and out.
For the mast use a 5mm diameter wooden dowel, and a 3mm one for the boom.
For the the sail we recommend a special water-resistant flat material usually easily found within any household (aka plastic), a heavy-duty garbage bag or shopping bag would likely work fine, but a nice synthetic fabric might look nicer.

The rudders are simply slid into the hinges, and the crossbar connectors, which also determines the width of the boat is put on. there are 3 crossbar connectors, open, midway or close.

the ballast holders go into the outriggers. each hull can accomodate 3 holders, which are sized to contain 20 dimes each.

the lines from the boom and the top of the mast to hold the sail are tied to the hooks on the back and front, respectively

use small rubberband to connect the little hook on the side outriggers to one of the three hooks on the central hull (depending on position). this helps maintain the boat in the desired configuration

FILES:
the files dubbed "no-movement" are the full boat. they are not meant to be printed in one go (although some printer might be able to do it. if they are, the parts wouldn't move.

the STL for the hulls (central, right, left) are present both as a single file or split in 3 parts for smaller printers (each has a front, middle and rear part) .
The rudder crossbars are also available both as a single file or split in two parts (left, right).
the split parts need to be glued. the outriggers use small internal connectors for strength

comments.text: I would recomend putting the coins in the middle, for easier movement trough waves if ur going RC, But nice project.
comments.author: anderikk

comments.text: Since this is currently designed for the hulls to be printed in 3 thirds, take advantage of that and make the hull much thinner, but put full bulkheads at each segment.  You could also enclose the hulls, again with a thin deck.  It'll ensure the hulls are water right, don't take on water.  The hulls can be much thinner, but this is where injection moulding out shines 3D printing.  But still worth a try.

title: Safe Storage for Counting Chambers - tested  (Fuchs-Rosenthal, Neubauer hemocytometers, etc)

description.text:
Counting chambers are expensive and tend to get scratched up after a while. This should help with the latter. Holds 8 hemocytometers.

2 Versions:

In version one, I tested rounding of the edges using the minkowski sum with a 1 mm sphere. See scad file (but beware of long render times when using the $fn function). This version must be scaled larger during slicing (ie 110%; as all walls become wider)

The second version omits the minkowski sum (however rendering at $fn=180 works with this version).

Print it yourself or order from my Shapeways shop. Currently I have added the second version only.
http://www.shapeways.com/shops/leanlabs

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a derivative of Sublime's Three jaw keyless chuck - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9179 , these are replacement jaws. From the discussion on that page hexitex may have some better jaws on the way, hopefully this principle can be applied to them too. I angled the base of the jaws a bit (1 or 2.5 degrees) such that when they are tightened, they will want to lean in towards whatever they are holding a tiny bit, applying more clamping force.

Note that there are four files, two each for 1 and 2.5 degrees. The difference in each pair is the orientation of the lean. The "reverse" files are in case you want to turn the jaw backwards to grip larger objects (so it will need to lean the other way)

comments.text: These should go a long way to improving the grip.

author: MarkU

description.text:
I created this project for the MakeItFloat Challenge and I wanted something that was useful beyond just the challenge. One thing I wanted was a way to carry drink in my pool, so to keep in spirit of the challenge my main focus to was carry as much coins as possible, since if I can carry a heavy load of metal, carrying liquids afterwards would work out.

Did some research on how things float and how various things work, like a boats, barges, pontoons, etc. The biggest factor I learned was center of gravity and weight needs to be distributed. Then I learned how a ballast tank is used to help balance a boat on water.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ballast_tank

The picture in the wiki page is what sparked the idea of making a cup holder that floats in my pool. Having the cup mostly submerged filled with cargo (coins, drinks, etc) will lower the center of gravity which should help with stability. From there I thought about giving the cup some kind of floaties to help keep it above water and add more balance.

Long story short I came up with a design using a honeycomb layout. The cup ring can have up to 6 pontoons connected to it. At first I tried creating the pontoons with 15% infill, so that I can trap alot of air inside, but it didn't help too much since it added weight to it. Second version of the pontoons were hollow and had a cap to trap more air while leaving out some of the weight.

The pontoons are the big piece of the design. it can connect to the ring and other pontoons, thus creating a modular system in which to create a floating structure. Stacking pontoons together add extra trapped air that can help add upward force while the cargo is applying a downward force since its heavier then water.

In the final design I added holes to the ring that allows me to add pegs that can hold a net. So instead of just holding solo cups, I can carry other things like cans of beer or bottles of water.

So with keeping with the rules of the challenge, using the ballast design and the pontoons I created something that floats. By making it modular I am able to print extra parts to allow the structure to expand and in doing so carry more coins, as many coins you need. For me with 6 pontoons and one cup I was able to handle a max load of 1.2lbs of coins.

In the end, you have a pretty versatile set of pieces that can be used to create a custom floating structure. It can be extended by using the peg holes or the slide rails. One such idea is to create a pontoon part that has a motor that can allow the structure to move. Can probable use the peg holes to add some rods to add a sail to the structure instead. Hell, you might have some other ideas I haven't even thought of by using theses.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aLfBG3FlMIY

comments.text: I really like this design. If I had a pool, you'd see some makes of it already. I hope you win the challenge. As always, its a pleasure following you. Keep up the great designs.

description.text:
I liked entomophile's remix of my earlier tripod mount. I had some M5x45 hex head screws lying around from another project, so I decided to make use of one for another tripod mount. Sized for an iPhone 6, may work with other phones. Fusion 360 file provided if you want to resize. See instructions for some notes on printing.

Update: v2 adds a side mount nut option for portrait mode.

The main base file can be printed entirely without supports. It makes use of some modeling tricks that assume a .20 mm layer height. Screw holes are purposely blocked with a single layer membrane to allow them to print without support; after printing, just drill through those. You can also just pick out the filament with some tweezers easily enough.

Files are oriented as they came out of the modeler, so reorient them for printing.

Knob should be printed top side down with support.

Requires an M5x45 screw, an M5 nut which goes into the nut trap in the middle, and a 1/4-20 nut for a tripod bolt which should be glued into the exterior nut-shaped hole.

comments.text: I made six of these for friends with various iphones, works great so thanks for the design.  To secure the 1/4X20 nuts I roughed up the flats with a file then used Loctite 2 part epoxy to secure them. This is an interlocking bracket for the Plugable PS2-USB4 Desktop Powerstrip.
http://plugable.com/products/ps2-usb4

The brackets securely hold the device in place, while still allowing easy access to all outlets and USB ports.

This was originally designed as an anti-theft device for a hotel chain, but also functions nicely for home use.

You can read more about it on Plugable's blog:
http://plugable.com/2015/07/10/3d-printed-bracket-for-desktop-powerstrip

The brackets held together with a 10mm M3 screw and an inset M3 Hex Nut. To mount the bracket (especially into drywall) I recommend using #6 screws and ribbed anchor. Here are the links to these products for your convenience:

M3 Screw: http://www.homedepot.com/p/Everbilt-M3-x-10-mm-Zinc-Plated-Phillips-Pan-Head-Machine-Screw-3-per-Bag-802708/204282658

M3 Hex Nuts: http://www.homedepot.com/p/Crown-Bolt-M3-0-5-Zinc-Plated-Steel-Hex-Nuts-5-Pack-37568/202836254

Screw and Anchor:http://www.homedepot.com/p/Crown-Bolt-4-6-x-7-8-in-Coarse-Yellow-Plastic-Ribbed-Anchors-with-Screws-10-Pack-00495/100338569

1. Insert hex nuts into insets of Right piece
  2. Slide powerstrip into Right piece
  3. Slide on Left piece
  4. Insert screw through aligned holes

Shown printed using Lulzbot Mini in PLA with 20% infill. ABS also works fine.

author: anita68

description.text:
I liked the idea published by Etienne Labuschagne in his thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:776611
I printed couple of clamps in ABS and played with the joint.
I noticed couple of issues with his clamps design:

  1. The joint is quite weak on forces in pull apart direction, though it works well when you push clamps toward to each other;
  2. The clamps are too spatial. Being using in my delta machine base it would lose significant amount of build volume in X/Y plane.

So I decided to make my own design to avoid the issues mentioned above.

The carriage designed for bronze bushings (8mm (d) x 12mm (D) x 15mm (L)) for 60mm distance between linear rods. It has adjustable GT2 belt tensioner. The carriage together with clamps give 24mm offset in printer radius (original Rostock's carriage gives 22mm). Note that the end-stop screws holders are at non-standard positions (for my custom design).

The platform together with clamps have 33mm offset in X/Y plane, the same as Rostock's platform. It has the same mounting holes and thickness, so I just was able to use hot-end holder and z-probe designed for Rostock platform use in this setup.

The mechanics in action - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lkXnUtAfmqY
It is still under testing and investigation. For the time being it's worked for ~ 22 hours in printing mode and all parameters are ok so far.

[2015-07-13 updated with some instructions]

[2016-03-03]
The joints still work fine. But my machine has other issues, so I decided to redesign some parts...
Investigating OnShape's features tried to reproduce the clamp. It came out better than old, more stiff and strong, so that I decided to put it here. Check new_clamp.stl and its source https://cad.onshape.com/documents/56d8a036e4b004367d917f94/w/7628c58a47d2143045023c61/e/6a2a69d3abcd3062a0b15a0a

All parts are made of ABS plastic. Printed with 0.2 mm layer height.

The carriage has built-in 'support' in screws holes, so it's not necessary to generate any other in addition.
The carriages can be used either with marble joints mechanics or with 'standard' Rostock's U-joints.
For second option use thing in rostock_carriage_adapter.stl. Note that in both cases the carriage offset is 24 mm.
In blind holes 3 mm threadings are cut.
The paired clamps or the adapter can be tightened with M3x14 mm bolts. It doesn't need to be very tight, so that threadings in plastic good enough. Of course other options like glueing are also possible. (There is a little disadvantage with these paired design, that heads of bolts contact surface in a little area, but still hold the clamps good enough. I'll try to develop better version of paired clamps to get rid of the issue.)

clamp.stl is the end of diagonal rod. It has 5mm blind hole to be attached to the rod. In my case the rods are knitting needles - aluminium tubes with quite thin walls and some sort of powder coating. They were cut in desired length and glued with epoxy resin on a stand that adjust length.

There are '*_w_support.stl' versions of clamps they are identical to other, but have areas with custom support. Such support helped me a little to prevent curling of plastic in thin areas.

Nothing special to say about platform.stl. Similar to carriages, M3 threadings need to be cut in blind holes to attach paired clamps with bolts.

clutch.stl is just a stub for those who want to make printable diagonal rods or use for other purposes.

comments.text: Printed the clamp only, tested with my kids marble toys, and surprised, it is stronger than magnetic joint
comments.author: susilon

comments.text: Just saw this. Nice! What keeps the joints from "twisting" on the marble and getting hung up on the side of the other half of the joint?
comments.author: roko11

comments.text:
Not sure I understand your question correctly...
Nothing keeps from twisting, every rod can rotate on its axis within +/- 20-25 degrees. Form of the clamp's "feelers" prevents them to block movement. And also mechanics doesn't reach critical angles so that it doesn't cause jams or other issues. After some time of printing the rods stabilized at their positions (some at central and other at utmost ). Changing the positions manually does not affect print quality and after some time the rods back to their cosy positions.
comments.author: roko11

comments.text: Thanks, that answers my question, I think I will try this out on my home-built Rostock. Right nowI am using 2 piece printed arms with the printed "U-joints".
comments.author: andyhomes

comments.text: I like your design way better than my own.  How is it holding up?  I am considering using it when building a delta for my Nephew.
comments.author: elabuschagne

comments.text: Hello Etienne
comments.author: elabuschagne

comments.text: probably some thermal shrinkage. it shrinked around the bushing because it will get cold because the bushing/bearing is made out of metal. the metal is harder than the plastic so the plastic will shrink around the bearing and make it crack. i reccomend friction welding up the crack. nice design. i like it really much. how is it compared to the original regarding: backlash, print quality, min layer height..? please post images of some items you've printed.
comments.author: andyhomes

comments.text: My previous setup was based on Rostock U-joints and carriages on ball bearings. The mechanics was not good enough mostly because of bearings of low quality. Another problem was bad linear rods (8 mm hardened steel), each had up to 0.75 mm bend on its length. I tried to make them straight, but no success. So I decided to try bronze bushings on stainless steel. Even though new linear rods also not perfect (up to 0.25 mm bend) I've got significant improvements. New system has no backlash at all.

Being concerned about fumes, I built a vented enclosure for my Lulzbot Mini.

the box is 50 cm square and 53 cm high. I wouldn't recommend anything smaller if you want to enclose the whole machine. It's made from polycarbonate with an angle aluminum frame. The corner brackets and hinges were printed with ABS. The knob, latch, hose flange and 1-4 inch adapter were printed with PCTPE. I tried a 2 inch PC fan but it wasn't strong enough so I went with the 4 inch dryer duct fan seen attached to a piece of black PVC sheet stuck in the window.
The box on top holding the filament spool is a Rubbermaid one that fits perfectly. The filament runs through 4mm ID PTFE tubing with nice and snug 3/8 inch grommets for both ends and desicant beads in the box to keep the filament nice and dry - a must for nylon.
The machine is attached to a Raspberry Pi (barely visible on the right) running Octoprint.
An added bonus is that the printer noise is significantly muffled.
Attached are the scad files for the printed parts.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5atROO0qKBG

The Z-Axis follower is designed to be inserted into one or both sides of the z-axis ToM where the press-fit bearing would go in-between the top and bottom z-axis pieces.  This is an untested prototype that I thought I would put on thingiverse to see if anyone saw any obvious flaws.  I will be printing this soon to try it out.
The goal was to make it fit inside the regular z-axis constraints and require minimal modification to the z-axis (4 screw holes currently).
There are obviously no bearings on one side due to space constraints, but I was hoping having two of these would essentially force the z-axis to push against the inside bearings.
If this works it would probably wise to add screw holes to secure it to the z-axis side pieces to improve rigidity.
The design is ugly and boring but it is somewhat easy to modify.  I used Sketchup which I know is disappointing to many, but I am a visual person and struggle with OpenSCAD.

I suspect that 6 bearings is overkill. You could probably get by with 4. Two on the inside, one on the bottom back, and one top front. I suspect this is where most of the pressure will be as the z-axis tends to want to tilt forward. This uses 693 bearings. I ordered 693ZZ (3X8X4) bearings off eBay. I will first print out just the bottom 4mm with the rod hole to make sure it all matches up then print the whole thing. When I print it out I'll update this. In the end you probably want to try these more polished options instead: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8823 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6184

description.text:
Holder for inductive sensor, for the sunhokey 3d printer ver.2015

This holder allows to mount the sensor to the hot end mount, made by projectearth7 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:818852, enabling the activation of the autoleveling routine in the Marlin firmware.

https://youtu.be/LtTV-hThzyY

PLA 30% infill, made with SLIC3R software, 0.3mm Layers

To print PLA plastic It has been holding very well. It may not be suitable for the ABS temperatures.

1.- Most sensors use 12v, this signal can't be put directly to the MSK mother board. A voltage divider can be implemented, I prefer to use an optocoupler. http://s4.postimg.org/yzllrve8t/IMG_20150922_222517280.jpg

2.-The output from the optocoupler can be connected to the Z axis limit switch pins. The Red cable provides +5V, Black wire is Ground, and the Blue wire is the signal of the limit switch.
http://s22.postimg.org/it2mmh98x/IMG_20150922_230331293.jpg

3.- Check the instructions from Thomas Sanladerer in the following video to configure the firmware.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EcGFLwj0pnA

PD. Test before you power the sensor, 12V signal can damage the the inputs in the Arduino Mega MKS Gen-2z v1.1 motherboard.

description.text:
This is a modification of my own Da Vinci Code Cryptex

The password is now customizable and there are clicking noises when you turn the rings.

You need five pins, five clicker and two decoshapes. The other parts only have to be printed once.

The inner letterring locks the tube. The outer letterring contents the letters. The special shape between inner and outer ring make costumizing possible.

You don't need to print the pins! You can take 3 mm filament, straighten it and cut it 5 times to 9mm length.
Thanks for the nice idea trepisky!

If you want to paint the cryptex, do this before assembly!

At first take the outer_tube and take one clicker. Fit the clicker into the first recess and press it down with a flat screwdriver. At the same time slide the fist letterring (C) over the clicker till it is flush to the outer tube. Repeat this process for all letterings (c,r,y,p,t) and take some superglue to fit the end piece over the outer tube to fix all.

The second part ist the assembly of the inner tube. Take the inner_tube and fit the pins into the holes. Take some superglue to fix them, if this is necessary.
the last part is glueing the deco_shapes on the flat front sides of the outer- and the inner-tube.

Make the antique look:
At first you have to color the cryptex completely in gold. After the color is dry, you take a old cloth, lay it down and make some lays. Now carefully put some black high fluent color on it. The last thing you have to do is to roll the Cryptex over that cloth. After some trials you can find out the right dose of color.

Now your finished. Please tell me your experiences.

And the most important: have fun!

comments.text:
Try to print simultaneously, not part after part. If you print part after part, they will get too hot. Print not too fast and I recommend to use PLA because you can cool PLA and it is more stiff than ABS.
Use blue tape.
comments.author: kevintwilson

comments.text: So I got it and this is what I did. Some may say no kidding. But hey i'm new at this. One the orientation of the object threw me I tried a couple of ways to find that the best was on its side. Second I used a speed of only 5, its small it doesn't take long. Used PLA.  with the .1 layer height. So I have a robo 3d plus and have a heated bed, glue worked fine. I used 215 print and 65 bed. I printed One at a time so the nozzle did not drag over such a small layer. I also used 3 skirts to make sure the filament was flowing. I pre heated, manually ran the extruder a couple of times. The thing runs a 9 point auto calibrate so in that time the plastic gets pulled back in hence the skirts. sure there may be other ways, like telling the Gcode not to calibrate since its so small anyways. but it worked.

comments.text:
I had the same problem with the falling out clickers on one of my builds. The reason of this problem is the round edge the printer makes. You have to cut the clicker a little bit. For the best with a sharp knife or a file. You simply need sharp edges. The same, and more important, is the edge in the outer tube, where the clickers fit in. It should be sharp too.
Use this kind of blade for the easyest way of cutting:
http://shop.objednavka.com/992-2504-thickbox/presny-skalpel-s-nahradnou-cepelou.jpg
(paper cutting knife with a sharp tip)

'Picar3D aquarium filter pipes' are probably one of the best 3D-printed bio-filter mediums available on Thingiverse today.

The filter pipes are a fully biological filter material for all internal, external and trickle filter systems and are an excellent choice for small filters.

The 3D printed filter pipes provides anaerobic bacteria an extremely large amount of different open-pored tunnel structures. This allows an ideal supply of the anaerobic bacteria with nutrients and a smallest amount of fresh water.
There are oxygen-poor conditions within the tunnels. This makes the bacteria crack nitrate to get enough oxygen. Consequently, they continuously break down nitrate, and the aquarium water remains low in nitrate.

-Pre-filter with fibre-wool to prevent large particles from entering the bio-filter.

Your fishes will be more happy than ever!

-Some pipes are more difficult to print then others-

title: Hexagon Mount for direct drive extruder included with Folgertech Prusa I3 kit

description.text: This is a remix with slight adjustments for a Hexagon hot end.

Remove the small bowden adapter from the top of the Hexagon hot end.

Use a length of 4mm OD PTFE pushed into the top of the hot end and extended up to the extruder.

For flexible filament printing consider reaming out the holes in the top half of the extruder to 4mm to fit a length of PTFE tube extending above the extruder. Slice (or drill to make it easier to create a round gap) a thin amount from the PTFE to allow the extruder gear to press against the filament. Print with flexible filament. :)

comments.text:
WARNING - At least one user has stated that the alignment is slightly off with this mounting block. I do not have a FolgerTech to test with.

This is a simple apple watch support that you can use in different ways without adding any other thing and getting the watch position that you prefer. The ring float letting you accommodate the watch face in the position you prefer. You can also put the watch horizontally.

I found the ring can be printed in any position but horizontally. The base also print in the natural correct position without any support. You need to clean the base holes carefully to make the ring fit better.

I use 2.5 mm layer height on my Printrbot Play to print my pieces. The ring is very tight to fit the charger unit and hold it in place even when the watch is removed. If you printer is very well setup you may print it without any size adjustment.

author: dsnettleton

description.text:
Basically you print 2 Long Sides and 2 Short Sides of these and move the gantry as close to "home" as possible and then use these to check to see if the gantry conduit is square with the XY support conduit.

If your Machine is out of square just a little then before you start your "print" in RH just use these as a guide and apply a light squeeze to gantry support and the xy conduit until it is perfectly square then in RH's manual controls move that axis .1mm in a direction towards the square check. The holding force will hold the machine in square on that axis during your print as long as you don't do an emergency stop in between.
Print 4 of them with tall layers and very low infill this is just a part to check your machine.

author: actingcam

description.text:
This case is build around a Raspberry Pi A+ and a Adafruit PiTFT 2.4" HAT with the main goal of being as compact/small as possible (only 17mm high! )

Inspired by Adafruits very nice Pocket PiGRRL

To achieve this the pin-sockets that came with the pitft was replaced by a cut down ic-socket and the raspberry pins where shortened - so that the pcb of the pitft sits (almost) directly on the highest components: the hdmi and usb sockets on the raspberry.

uses M3 nuts, glued into the top part (make sure to clear the round recess for the screw beforehand!)
and M3x16 countersunk screws to hold everything together

yes - the mounting holes on the raspberry and its hat are onlye 2,5mm - but they are easily widened to fit the more common screw size :-P

Note: on the pitft-pcb has a diode (D1) that is used to control the backlight via pwm. this diode hits the hdmi connector which is why i removed a bit of the metal casing to save a little bit more height :-P

comments.text: I might modify this design and put inside a raspberry pi zero, because I could maybe find room for a battery, and I wouldn't have to unsolder the GPIO pins. I`ve adapted the excellent spring engine made by GZUMWALT (Wheelie, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:452248 ) to create this paddles boat.
I just made some changes to obtain a better adaptation to the water environment;
The spring thickness has been reduced (-0,4mm) in order to have a less powerful engine, not necessary with a boat. This also let an increased autonomy and it’s easier to charge.
The thickness of the gears has been increased, the original version gave me some precision problems, probably due to my printer (actually I mount a 0,5 mm nozzle)
NB. The actual length of the boat is 220mm, and it has been a difficult task to print it on my OrdBot. In a future evolution I will try to reduce this dimension, bearing in mind that the weight of the motor is important.
Floatation tests have been very satisfactory and the boat was really appreciated by my daughter!
Update 14 July 2015: added new reduced hull (lenght 195 mm) tested successfully.

Please check also my new project, the Spring powered Catamaran (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1037341). Thanks

All the engine parts are in PLA.
All printed with 100% infill, and layer thickness of 0,4mm.

description.text: This small tabletop bowling game was made for my children and friends birthday party. Make a set of 5 or 10 pins, add a standard marble (glass preferable) and play. No rental shoes required.

This was fabricated on a MakerBot Replicator (2012 model) Dual, using the standard MBI Black and White ABS 1.80mm filament, and with MakerWare 2.01 on medium quality with 2 shells, 15% infill.  ABS extrusion temperature was set to 230C and HBP was set to 110C.  A layer of ABSynthe (scrap ABS plus acetone) was spread on the kapton tape to improve adhesion.  
To get the proper dual extrusion I opened the white STL first, and then added the red/black STL layer second.  On my system the black spool was on the right extruder, and the white spool on the left, so I had to set the colors in the MakerWare preferences, and then select the white objects and change them from the default right extruder to the correct left extruder.  
When building an array of pins, you will need to use a raft, otherwise near the top of the pin structure (just below the second color) the pins will get knocked/dragged down by any ooze from the secondary extruder head (see the third image for what an afternoon of printing will give you without a raft). MakerWare will NOT generate a raft when dual-strusion is required (gahh!).  To fix this  I manually created a 0.54mm flat surface, added it to the THING in MakerWare, and moved the pin array "up" by 0.54mm (make sure to select both the white and the black/red pieces of the pin when moving it vertically).  Arrays can be loose, gridded, staggered or maximally packed for density.  
NOTE: If you print a single pin on a MakerBot Replicator Dual, you will see the ooze effect from the inactive toolhead brushing the print during the build at every-other layer increment due to the GCODE tool-change command. The only way to get a really clean print as far as I can tell is to watch the print like a hawk and use a knife to scrape off the ooze from the inactive extruder.  Print time for a single pin with the settings above was 22m on a pre-heated system.  
Modeling:  
To create the pin model in Rhino (OS X), I first created the contour using "curve through points". To find the points for the curve I created  simple boxes representing the outer dimensions of the pin, and then created POINT objects at the verticies. Then select curve through point and use the vertex points for the outer curve (bottom to mid-point) and separate curve for the mid-point through to top (from just below the black/red band up to the top of the pin). Once a full profile curve is available, to create a water-tight solid I use "revolve around axis".  Once this is complete to add the color band in the middle of the pin I created two "surface from planar curves", one at the bottom of the black/red band, and one at the top of the band. Then Boolean split using the surfaces just created as the cutting objects.  This leaves us with 3 distinct watertight solids, the base, the colored band, and the top.  Export the two white objects into one file, and the black/red band into the other file.

author: RayvenMaker

description.text:
I've been trying out Autodesk Memento and decided to make a turntable to make shooting multiple shoots more precise.
I used MOI for the design work.
At 1:1 the turntable is rather large but the largest parts fit OK on my Ultimaker 1.
Most of the parts were made on the Ultimaker in PLA (mostly Bilby 3D PLA). However the puller, wedge and keepers were made on a Robox using Robox ABS. No special reason for this.
All the screws are 3mm button head cap screws. 14-off 10mm and 3-off 15mm long.
The spring O/D is 7mm. Free length 19mm Solid height 4mm. Wire diameter .65mm.
I haven't tried using the turntable without the spring. I suspect that the spring is of little benefit.
The mounts are to elevate the photo subject above the rest of the turntable for easier processing.
The large central mount is shown. Also included in the stl files is a smaller mount. 3 or 4 (or more) of these could used in the 10mm holes for larger objects.
For stability I've mounted the turntable on a piece of wood. The mounting screws are accessible via the outermost 10mm holes.

Printing is fairly straightforward (except the keepers, see below) but check the orientation before proceeding.

The keepers I printed upright (as in the photos) using brim and support.

title: MakerGear M2 Dual Extruder Dial Indicator Mount

description.text: This is a modified MakerGear M2 "Dual Harness and Fan Support". I added a branch where a dial indicator can be mounted with a 1/4-20 screw (or similar sized metric screw); note that you'll need to tap the hole or drill it out bigger. The dial indicator needs to have a mountable back (you can print a mountable back, one of these 3d model sites has a model of one). REMOVE THE DIAL INDICATOR BEFORE YOU PRINT.

REORIENT WITH FAN MOUNT SURFACE ON PRINTER BED BEFORE YOU PRINT. You'll need to add supports to print this probably. The original part from MakerGear had signs of supports and I printed my modified version with supports.

comments.text: This is a good design for an M2 Dual.  The pictures don't fully show the horizontal screw hole in the back for the dial indicator.  It's well positioned and does a good job of adding capability for quick bed levelling without having to take a bunch of screws in and out as some of the other M2 designs require.  If you have an M2 with Dual extruders, give this one a try.
comments.author: greenhornet

author: LazerMech

description.text:
Simple pill box... This is my very first ever design and use of a CAD program, so please be gentle.

EDIT/NEW: I added Pill Box MKII.. This one has two sliders, dates printed on the slider lids, and rails are triangular to make them much more printer friendly.. The lids in this version slide in much smoother and, again, lock in at the end with a "click".
The two file for this are "z-base-double.stl" and "z-pill-box-lid-double-dated-BOTH.stl"
I added some photos of the new box, also.

ORIGINAL POST (re:Single lid version)
The base has rails for the lid to slide in that may need supports.. They printed fine on my printer without any, but I still plan on tweaking the design a little so that it has triangular grooves instead of rectangular, so that it's more printer-friendly.

The lid is tapered on 3 sides to allow smoother sliding in and out. The front of the lid has a raised ledge to grab for opening and closing, and also thickens out on the sides (with no tapering) right at the end. This allows the lid to "click" and sort of "lock" at the very end so it doesn't slide out on its own.

Hope this has use for someone.

title: Tape Mount to collect printer debris

description.text:
I’ve gotten tired of bits of plastic showing up all over the place. I either miss the trash can and have to pick stuff up or there are several bits that need to be collected. Well, this simple tool will allow you to just stick the bits to the tape as you go, standing right in front of the machine. I’m finding this very convenient.

Now, the tool will hold any tape width up to 3.75 inches. So, if you got 2 inch or even 1 inch wide tape the tool still works for you. The smaller bits get pretty adhered to the tape so little chance of them being knocked off.

I showed how to remove the tape but to install the tape, the process is exactly the same just reversed. Keep sticky side up and only the two ends adhere to the tool.

I chose to use two Velcro tabs for mounting. This way you can mount it anywhere convenient for you. I like the upper right frame of the printer for my Replicator. But, on the side or on the desk, your needs and imagination will dictate location.
Enjoy, Reamo

title: Traxxas Slash 2WD body mount extenders for Ford Raptor body

description.text:
These are some simple spacers to raise the body mounts on a 2WD Traxxas Slash to accept a Ford Raptor body.
Learn more about the process at www.RCDetails.ca!

Print with 3 shells and at least 50% infill. Any more and it is overkill. Acetone fuses it all together if you are concerned.
Use some appropriate length 3mm hardware. Make sure there is good thread purchase, you don't want to core out the threads in the body mount by not using bolts long enough.
Screw 'em on, pin on the body and kick some ass!

I don't have a whole lot of experience with the Arduino, but I find that I often use it as a platform to quickly prototype circuits and test out components.  Since I've only got one, this generally means that I have to pull it from whatever project it happens to be currently connected up to use it for prototyping/debugging something else and hook it back up again later.
Because of this, I created this simple wiring harness so I can easily move my Arduino from one project to the next and back again with little hassle.  You can freely insert jumper wires and devices with 0.1" headers with the shield on for prototyping.  Then when you have the Arduino wired up how you like it, just clamp the jumper wires down to make it a little more permanent.
I also sometimes wire up miscellaneous connectors for prototyping, like the 15-pin PC joystick connector pictured, and I can connect those directly to the Arduino and not have to worry as much about accidentally pulling wires out as I'm connecting devices and moving them around with the shield installed.  There's also plenty of space to access the reset button and the ISP header on my Duemilanove board should I need them.

All parts are cut from 1/8" clear acrylic and I used 3/8" #6 screws to fasten the clamps down.
TIP: You'll likely need to clean out the holes for the 0.1" headers with a needle or a push pin, as the small cylinder of acrylic left from cutting the holes will likely get stuck in them.  Alternatively, you can also go over the holes twice when you cut out the shield.  This worked well for me and can easily be done by copy/pasting another set of holes on top of the existing ones.
You may have noticed in the pictures that one of the wire clamps is a bit longer than the other.  This was one of the clamps I was using when I made my first prototype and I wanted to see if I could make the clamps spring loaded (the edges hung over the edge so you could easily pull the clamp up).  I found that it was easy to do so with some simple hardware, but it didn't work very well (mainly because it was hard to remove jumper wires).  I'd really like to find a way to simply fold the clamps over the wires from the outside and lock them in place...

description.text:
This is the 5th version of my printable linear rail, I've gotten everything to finally work correctly. This can be used as a drop in replacement for a 3d printer's X or Y axis. It's rail system is designed to connect together to form any needed length. This machine hopefully will be my entry for the Gada prize. Update 06/16/2011:
I worked out a few modifications to the shuttle. Now the lower half of the shuttle can be printed as well, this removes:
4x 5/16(8mm) nuts
2x 5/16(8mm) bolts
2x 5/16 washers -The next to go is going to be replacing the front 5/16(8mm) hardware with all printed parts. I'm trying to pare this down just the motor and the printed parts. -I also redesigned the Large helical gear to incorporate the 608 bearing embedded inside of it. think this is an advantage of trying to use 2 bearings in the pillow block. The large helical gear is also now held in place by a printed 8mm bolt 40mm long. This removes one additional piece of hardware. -The shuttle top now has 4 mounting holes, although I'm just securing the motor with 2 at this point. -I printed 2 new 3-segment rails, redesigned lower half of shuttle to be printed.
-I also added 2 new pics of the x/y gantry system and uploaded all new parts - I should have another video. Update 04/30/2013
It's been brought to my attention that the rack file was missing from this. I have uploaded both the rack stl and scad file. Enjoy! Here is a youtube video of it in action:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ScJMPw6UPtw Comments and feedback are welcome.

You'll need to print at least 2 rails, preferably more. Tolerances are tight, you may need to file a few things to fit. I'm working on a complete PDF with pix and assembly instructions, but for now: First,
Connect rails segments together by hammering in the connector block halfway, and then applying a little super glue afterwords. Coat the matching rail face with superglue or epoxy and hammer in the other side of the rail. -After connecting rail segments together, use a < 8mm block with medium grit sand paper to sand inside the rails where the shuttle rides so there are no seams. You can "feel" the seams by running the completed shuttle up and down the rail Additional hardware needed for the shuttle:
1x 30mm 5/16 bolts (or 8mm)
2x matching nuts
1x flat 5/16 washers
4x 608 bearings
1x NEMA 17 stepper motor
3x M3 bolts
1x M3 nut

This is a scan of a slip cast piggy bank i made while in middle school years back in a previous century. The original is on the left. The file is hollow and includes a hole at the bottom for a rubber stopper as well as a coin slot in the piggies head.
He was scanned using an older model NextEngine with the 32 bit Proscan software, then cleaned up using 3D Coat. He is sized to print bottom up on a Rep2, but should scale up easily. I recommend using supports for his chins and snout. Since he is hollow, if you set supports automatically then you will get support material inside him. Make the infill percentage low if not zero since it is a thin walled object.
We will talk more about this guy and much more 3D Printing and 3D Scanning topics on the 3D Printing Today Podcast!!
threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com
Also...
threedprintingtoday.com for all our show related posts and stuff.

I just bought some spools from Matter hackers that have a 30mm center hole. So I've designed an adapter that slides on the original wheels. This adapter is built in 2 pieces so you can print different center piece that will match your spool holes.

You need to print the base and the axle. To print the base you need supports. I've printed mine rotated (STL included) so the supports are easier to remove. You just have to skrew the two pieces and slide onto your original wheels. I've included the Inventor files, if you want to design a different spool diameter axle. If you don't have access to inventor, leave a message and I will upload the diameter that will fit your needs. Notes:
  • The matter hackers spools are relatively narrow, So I've added a large cartboard disk to avoid that the filament falls down.
  • I've moved my wheels on top of the 3dTouch using the coder holes for the bolt. It the best solution i found to avoid fimalent snapping in the plastic tubes.

description.text:
Updated Description: This is a scale model of the Gateway arch in St. Louis Mo. The .stl is at a scale of 1 millimeter equals 1 foot. The .thing file is scaled down from there to fit on my printer. I found a description of the mathematics of the design and used that to replicate the structure. I do all of my design work in Mathematica so the formulas came in handy. The cross sections of the arch are equilateral triangles that vary in a linear fashion with the altitude of the centroid from 54 foot on an edge to 17 feet. The centroids of these triangles are on a weighted centenary curve so that the total height is equal to the the total width.

The first version is just the arch on a base. On the second version I modified the base to look like the entryways to the visitors center that is under the ground beneath the arch. Also, the elliptical patches of grass on the surface are not to scale (as the grass is not actually 5 feet tall).

The Recorder is one of the oldest flutes around that's still in use. The Recorder is one the main reasons the Ocarina lost much of its hold over the musical domain. It grew to its greatest popularity during the Renaissance. The modern flute we use today like the Recorder's younger brother- both were developed side by side historically. The soprano Recorder is the most common one used today. One can say that playing the Recorder remains as one of the easier things to do among the woodwind instruments. The recorder gets its name from the early meaning of 'record', which means 'to practice music'. The recorder is named 'Flauto' in Portuguese and Spanish. Over the passing of time however, it was discovered that the modern concert flute was richer in tones and better sounding than the recorder. That, coupled with the exponential rise in popularity of orchestras, led to the decline of the recorder. The flute is a musical instrument of the woodwind family. Unlike woodwind instruments with reeds, a flute is an aerophone or reedless wind instrument that produces its sound from the flow of air across an opening. According to the instrument classification of HornbostelÃ¢Â€Â“Sachs, flutes are categorized as edge-blown aerophones.
A musician who plays the flute can be referred to as a flute player, a flautist,[1] a flutist,[2] or, less commonly, a fluter.[3][4][5][6] The term flutenist, found in English up to the 18th century, is no longer used.[7]
Aside from the voice, flutes are the earliest known musical instruments. A number of flutes dating to about 43,000 to 35,000 years ago have been found in the Swabian Alb region of Germany. These flutes demonstrate that a developed musical tradition existed from the earliest period of modern human presence in Europe.[8][9] La flauta dulce o flauta de pico es un instrumento de viento muy antiguo. Popular desde la Edad Media hasta finales del Barroco, fue quedando relegado su uso al desarrollarse la orquesta clÃƒÂ¡sica, poblada de instrumentos mÃƒÂ¡s sonoros. A partir del siglo XX retorna de los museos, en principio por el interÃƒÂ©s de interpretar la mÃƒÂºsica renacentista y barroca con sus instrumentos originales, pero su difusiÃƒÂ³n mundial se basa en las posibilidades pedagÃƒÂ³gicas como herramienta para la iniciaciÃƒÂ³n musical.

title: Button replacement for Back-Bone Ribcage Mod kit (gopro hero4 black)

description.text:
This is a replacement button for the modification kit "Ribcage" by Back-Bone, which converts a gopro hero 4 black to allow interchangeable lenses.

The button of the kit is black, but I found it is practical to change its color for identification purposes, and to add a little color...

For optimal results, I printed at 0.2mm layer height upto 3.2mm, and above at 0.1mm layer height.

The openscad source is provided in case the button does not fit.

Designed this for my new n3ds. if you own one you know the flat stick is not comfortable. In designing it, i discovered just how challenging it is to create one that fits well, as well as, doesn't interfere with the movement of the stick. it goes on, not too tight but just enough to work really well when playing. feels great. Dont know if its the same size for other 3ds models but it prints quick so give it a try and let me know.
best when printed upside down (thumb surface at the bottom)

comments.text: My 3DS circle pad gets stuck because the button gets indented somehow. this extender looks like it will solve my problem perfectly! I am printing it out tonight on my Da Vinci Jr; I will let you know how it goes! Thanks for taking the time to design and post this model, you may have saved me $200!!

title: Try printing it with this rotated file

description.text:
I rotated the file to lay flat on its side, you should need support.
Print slow speed and all should be well.
The part will be stronger printed this way.

author: galiettd

description.text: The harness containing the wires for the z motor kept sagging and getting in the way of the bed as it moved back and forth. I designed a simple prop to secure it just upright enough not to get in the way, without adding movement restrictions of the wires.
just use double sided tape on the 3 flat surfaces.
